results.title: Drowning: facts and myths
results.brief_description: A water safety film showing examples of drowning cases that illustrate these safety rules: never swim alone, always watch young children when they are in the water, fence backyard swimming pools, don’t depend on inflatables and wear lifejackets when boating.
results.description: A water safety film showing examples of drowning cases that illustrate these safety rules: never swim alone, always watch young children when they are in the water, fence backyard swimming pools, don’t depend on inflatables and wear lifejackets when boating.

results.title: Drowning by numbers
results.creator_credit: Film Four International, Kees Kasander, Denis Wigman and Peter Greenaway
results.brief_description: A tale of three women with the same name, whose solidarity with one another brings about three copy-cat murders. They drown their husbands - one in a tin bath, one in the sea and one in a swimming pool. An ironic, black comedy that celebrates the English obsession with gameplaying, sex and death. Stars Joan Plowright, Juliet Stevenson, Joely Richardson and Bernard Hill.

results.title: Drown-proofing
results.creator_credit: Norman Keziere, Joe Hayward and Moreland-Latchford Productions
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Outdoor Education and Recreation”.
Designed to help teach swimmers and non-swimmers alike how to survive a water accident, by showing how to stay afloat and travel in water, even if you have never learned to swim. The majority of men and women can remain on the surface in fresh water, and in salt water the human body is even more buoyant.

results.title: Drought in Botswana
results.creator_credit: United Nations, Food and Agriculture Organization of the United Nations and Harold Eastwood
results.brief_description: Illustrates the World Food Program famine relief in Botswana which began in 1965 after five years of drought had decimated the country. Relief was provided for over 100,000 Kalahari bushmen. Covers tribal traditions and all aspects of the assistance program.

results.title: Drought grips Riverina
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Cinesound Review”.
An edition of the weekly Cinesound newsreel (Ep. 679) consisting of one “full-reel” item: “Drought grips Riverina”, alerting the public to the severity of the drought, and criticising the destructive abuse of the land by farmers who overstock. Suitable for middle and upper secondary levels.

results.title: Drought feeding
results.brief_description: Discusses the various fuel values of different foodstuffs and gives much information on drought feeding of stock. Based on scientific investigations made by the Australian wool board into the subject of drought feeding of sheep, this film shows the fuel value of various types of supplementary fodder, taking into account both cost and nutritive value. The Wool Board makes available to pastoralists a Drought Feed Calculator, together with other tables relating to drought feeding, are clearly presented in this film.

results.title: Drought (D)
results.creator_credit: Golden Dolphin, Robert Loader and Tristram Miall
results.brief_description: Powerful introduction to drought and other dramatic aspects of Australia’s climate, including bushfires, floods, cyclones. Examines how native plants and animals have adapted to these conditions, and looks at the history of European occupation. WARNING: Contains disturbing scenes of the agonising death of a herd of wild horses at a dry water hole and recommend viewing suitable for upper secondary student level only.

results.title: Dropping out: broken dreams
results.brief_description: This program teaches that education means options through the personal experiences of six adolescent students who have dropped out of school, experienced the realities of job hunting and decided for themselves that they need an education. This video is suitable for career studies and personal development and is relevant to the Australian situation.

results.title: Drop kick eulogy
results.brief_description:
A couple of Rupanyup stalwarts recount the days when the drop kick was king, before the invention of the more reliable but less skillful ‘drop punt’.

Thank you to Bob Baker, Jack Dunlop, Dawn Teasdale and the Rupanyup Football Club. Archival film by John Teasdale.

TRANSCRIPT

[MEN SHOUTING]

[WHISTLES BLOWING]

[CROWD CHEERING]

BOB BAKER: I’d say it was about 1950, I started. And in those days, it was either a dropkick or a torp. And of course, the high-mark blokes always went crook if you weren’t kicking a dropkick, because they’d have a lark making torpedo kicks.

The blokes who kicked good dropkicks were worth watching, but a lot of us, myself included, weren’t good dropkicks. And dropkicks were a problem because the ground, the surface changed. And OK, the natural base could always get away. But all the same, every now and again, you’d go to a different ground. Like you’d go up to the sandy ground up at Jeparit and even our best fellows would kick a grounder occasionally.

[CROWD CHEERING]

JACK DUNLOP: I loved it, actually. We were always doing it, from the time we first went to school. Because the drop punt had never been thought of when I gave it away. So we fancied it as a distance kick, on fine days. You didn’t do it on a wind day.

Mainly the biggest thing with dropkicking was timing. If you didn’t time it, it didn’t go anywhere. But no, in later years, we had some pretty good big men, good high marks here. And your ambition was to get it as far as you could. They had a fair idea how far you could kick it, and you would kick to a contest. Not like today, where they won’t kick to a contest at all.

[MEN SHOUTING]

[CROWD CHEERING]

Those days, when they really used it, they all took their marks, went back and had their shots at goal and that. And they’d take up here but top it behind the head like this. Nobody ever does that these days.

When you take a mark, you’ve got the ball. You’re got to have your ball in your hand ready, because there might be a handball or something. And those sort of things went out in the early ‘50s.

ONLOOKER: Let fly, Richie!

BOB BAKER: Well, every coach I had tried to teach me how to kick dropkicks, and I never really mastered dropkicks. I remember playing one day and Jim Gulley was coaching, and I was playing center halfback. And Gulley didn’t mind me kicking them, because everyone else thought I’d kick them further than I did. And Gulley would lead up the ground and the center halfback wouldn’t follow him, because he thought he was getting too close to me. But that’s as far as I could kick the jolly things.

[MEN SHOUTING]

[CROWD CHEERING]

Nowadays with the drop punt, everyone kicks a drop punt and the balls so easy to handle. It doesn’t matter which leg you’re kicking. You’ve still got the ball in the same position to kick it. And it’s made a lot of difference to football, the drop punt, has. It’s one of the biggest challenges in the whole lot, I’d say.
